The dust in the arena tasted of rust and regret. Lena Verhoeven knew the flavour well. It was the grit of the Kempen soil, drier than it had any right to be, churned into a fine, ochre cloud by the hooves of her quarter horse, Balthazar. From the stands, a corrugated iron roof over splintering wooden planks, it probably looked poetic. A lone cowgirl, a silhouette against the low-slung Belgian sun, carving patterns into the earth. Up close, it was just sweat and the sting of dirt in her eyes. Balthazar snorted, his breath a hot, damp puff against her denim-clad thigh. He was a good boy. Better than most people she knew. Solid and dependable and blissfully unaware of the fractures in her own courage.

She urged him into a sliding stop, the climax of a reining pattern she’d been practicing until her muscles screamed in protest. Dirt flew, a wave breaking against an invisible shore. For a moment, it was perfect. The fluid motion, the complete trust between horse and rider, the brief, beautiful silence after the spray of earth settled. This was why she did it. This was the antidote to Antwerp’s cramped streets, to the suffocating politeness of city life, to the ghost of her father who had loved the idea of America more than the reality of Belgium. He'd left her his collection of worn-out Louis L'Amour paperbacks and a deep-seated yearning for wide-open spaces she had to manufacture for herself in a country the size of a postage stamp.

“Pretty,” a voice drawled, dripping with the kind of false admiration that was sharper than any insult. “For a city girl.”

Lena didn’t have to look. Dirk Martens. He was leaning against the fence, arms crossed over his chest, a self-satisfied smirk playing on his lips. He was everything she wasn’t: born to this life, his family’s farm sprawling over the next hill, his boots scuffed with authentic manure, not just arena dust. He wore the cowboy hat and the worn jeans not as a costume, but as a uniform. To him, she was a dilettante, a tourist in his world.

“Just trying to keep up with you old-timers, Dirk,” she said, her voice steady as she walked Balthazar in a cool-down circle. Don’t let him see it gets to you. That was rule number one.

“You’d have to get up a lot earlier to keep up,” he chuckled, spitting a stream of something brown near his boots. “Takes more than a fancy hat. Takes grit. Real grit.”

Lena just nodded, focusing on the rhythmic creak of her saddle. The argument was as old and tired as the leather of her reins. She could outride him any day of the week and they both knew it. Her turns were tighter, her stops cleaner. She had a finesse born from obsessive practice, a desperate need to prove she belonged. Dirk had raw, lazy talent and the validation of his birthright. It made him cocky and cruel.

Her circuit brought her closer to the edge of the arena, near the ramshackle gate that led out to the stables. And that’s when she heard it.

A sound that wasn't the gentle nicker of a horse or the lazy buzz of a fly. It was a sharp, interrogating squawk. A territorial declaration. It sliced through the quiet evening air and straight into her spinal cord.

Her breath hitched. Her hands, which had been so relaxed on the reins moments before, clenched into white-knuckled fists. Balthazar, ever sensitive to his rider’s mood, tensed beneath her, his ears swivelling.

“Easy, boy,” she whispered, but the words were a flimsy shield against the wave of cold dread washing over her.

It was just out of sight, somewhere behind the peeling paint of the stable door. Another cry, this one more of a guttural, rolling crow. A boast. A threat. The sound swelled to fill the entire universe. The dusty arena shrank, the world narrowing to that single, terrible noise.

*Cluck-cluck-CRAWWWW*.

Lena’s heart hammered against her ribs like a trapped bird. A genuinely trapped bird, not the feathered demon that was now strutting into view. It emerged from behind the stable, a monstrosity of iridescent green and black tail-feathers, a blood-red comb wobbling arrogantly on its head. Its legs were a pale, scaly yellow, dinosaur-like, and its beady little eyes seemed to fix directly on her. It wasn't just a cockerel. It was *the* cockerel. Dirk’s prize-winning Mechelse Koekoek, a bird as belligerent and self-important as its owner. He called it ‘Generaal’.

The world began to tilt. The smell of dust and horse was replaced by a phantom scent of damp feathers and something metallic, like old blood. Her vision swam, the edges blurring into a dark tunnel. The cockerel at the end of it puffed out its chest, lowered its head, and took a scraping, aggressive step forward. In her mind, it wasn't a two-kilo bird. It was a raptor, a dragon, a feathered harbinger of a specific, buried horror. The memory, fragmented and terrible, flashed behind her eyes: small hands, a frantic chase, the corner of a coop, a flurry of wings, a sharp beak, pain, and a feeling of being utterly, terrifyingly smothered.

Balthazar whinnied, a high, nervous sound, reacting to the rigid terror that had seized his rider. Her legs were frozen. She couldn't move, couldn't breathe. The reins were slick with sweat in her hands.

Dirk’s laughter boomed from the fence. It was a harsh, ugly sound. “What’s the matter, Verhoeven? Scared of a little chicken? I thought you had grit!”

His words were distant, distorted, as if coming from underwater. All she could see were those unblinking eyes, that hooked beak. The Generaal took another step, then another, its walk a jerky parody of a march. It let out another piercing crow, a victory cry. And Lena’s carefully constructed composure shattered into a million pieces.

With a strangled cry, she yanked hard on the reins without meaning to, a pure panic reflex. Balthazar, confused and spooked by his rider’s terror and the sharp, unexpected command, reared up. It wasn’t a dramatic, filmic rear, but a startled, unbalanced jolt. For a split second, Lena was airborne, untethered from the saddle, before she came crashing down into the soft, unforgiving dust of the arena. The impact knocked the wind out of her, the taste of rust and regret filling her mouth. The last thing she saw before her eyes squeezed shut in humiliation was the cockerel, standing its ground, the undisputed king of the yard, and Dirk Martens, laughing so hard he had to hold onto the fence for support.

Pain was a secondary concern. It bloomed in her shoulder where she’d landed and radiated from her hip, a dull, throbbing protest. But it was nothing compared to the searing heat of humiliation that scorched her from the inside out. For a long, mortifying moment, she lay there, a tangle of limbs in the dirt, pretending the world had ceased to exist. If she didn't move, if she didn't open her eyes, maybe this would all be a bad dream. Maybe Dirk's hyena-like laughter wasn't echoing in the quiet evening, a soundtrack to her personal hell. Maybe the triumphant, world-conquering crow of that feathered demon hadn't just toppled her from her high horse, literally and figuratively. But the grit on her tongue was real, and the solid weight of her failure was pinning her to the ground more effectively than gravity.

A soft muzzle nudged her cheek, whiskery and warm. Balthazar. He snorted again, a low, worried rumble deep in his chest, his large, dark eye blinking down at her with what she could only interpret as profound equine concern. The gesture was her undoing. The dam of her composure, already fractured, finally broke. A hot tear escaped from under her tightly shut eyelid, carving a clean path through the grime on her cheek. She was mortified not for falling, but for scaring him. For her own ridiculous, childish terror being transmitted through the reins, through her very bones, into this magnificent animal who trusted her implicitly. He deserved a better rider, a braver partner. One who wasn't undone by a common farm animal.

“Well, I’ll be,” Dirk’s voice was closer now, laced with glee. Heavy boot steps crunched in the dirt. “The great Lena Verhoeven, brought down by Generaal. Maybe I should enter him in the reining competition instead of you. He’s clearly got more presence in the arena.” He loomed over her, a large shadow blocking the setting sun. “You alright down there, city girl? Need a hand, or are you just admiring the quality of our Kempen soil up close?”

Gritting her teeth, Lena pushed herself up onto her elbows. Every muscle ached, but the fire of anger was beginning to burn away the icy paralysis of her phobia. She ignored Dirk, focusing only on Balthazar. She reached up a shaky, dusty hand and stroked his nose. “It’s okay, boy. I’m okay. It was my fault.” Her voice was a hoarse whisper, meant for him alone. Balthazar nudged her again, a silent reassurance that passed between them, a bond Dirk could never understand. With a deep, shuddering breath that tasted of earth and defeat, she levered herself into a sitting position, the world swimming for a second before settling. The cockerel, Generaal, was still there by the stable door, preening a wing feather, occasionally glancing their way with an air of utter indifference, its work apparently done. To the bird, she was a momentary disturbance, now settled. To Lena, it remained a monster in the periphery, a pulsating beacon of her deepest shame.

Slowly, painfully, she got one knee under her and then stood, brushing futilely at the thick layer of ochre dust that now coated one entire side of her body. She kept her back to Dirk, determined not to give him the satisfaction of seeing her face. She gathered Balthazar’s reins, her movements stiff and clumsy. Her shoulder screamed, and she suspected a spectacular bruise was already forming on her hip, but she refused to limp. Pride, however battered, was the only armour she had left. She began to lead Balthazar towards the gate, her gaze fixed firmly on the splintering wood, pretending she was alone.

“Not even going to finish your practice?” Dirk’s taunt followed her, impossible to ignore. “What happens if a pigeon flies into the arena during the competition? You just going to throw yourself on the ground and forfeit?” His laughter followed, coarse and cruel. He didn't understand. He couldn't. For him, it was just a bird. For her, it was the rustle of straw in a dark corner, the sudden, explosive flapping, the feeling of being trapped and small as a furious bird twice the size of her childhood head descended upon her. The memory was a physical thing, a tightening in her chest, the phantom pain of a beak striking her forehead, right by her hairline. A tiny scar she could still feel with her fingertips if she tried.

At the gate, she stopped. She had to. Her hands trembled as she fumbled with the simple metal latch. It was her own arena, her own rented space. And she was being chased out of it. Not by Dirk, but by her own demons, goaded by his prize-winning fowl. For a fleeting second, she considered turning around, unleashing the torrent of angry, defensive words boiling in her gut. But she knew it would be a mistake. It would only feed his amusement. Silence was her only recourse, a weapon she wasn’t sure how to wield effectively but was the only one she could grasp.

With the latch finally open, she led Balthazar through the gate, not daring to look back. The rhythmic clop of his hooves on the harder-packed earth of the yard was a comforting sound. The sun had dipped below the corrugated roof of the stands now, casting long, distorted shadows that made the world look unfamiliar and strange. As she walked towards the stables, away from the arena, away from Dirk and his feathered henchman, the sting of humiliation began to curdle into something else. It hardened in her stomach, a cold, heavy knot of resolve. He thought she was a joke. A dilettante scared of a chicken. He had laughed at her, at her deepest, most private fear. Tonight, she had lost. But as she smoothed Balthazar’s mane, her dirt-streaked fingers stroking the familiar, solid warmth of him, Lena Verhoeven made a silent vow. This was not over. Not by a long shot.

The stable was her sanctuary, a low-ceilinged building that smelled of hay, leather, and the sweet, earthy scent of horse. The air was cool and still, a balm after the open, exposed arena. Each stall door was painted a faded blue, and her name, ‘L. Verhoeven’, was written on a small, neat plaque next to Balthazar’s stall, a small claim of territory in Dirk’s world—the stables were on his family's land, a fact he never let her forget. She led Balthazar into his spacious box, the thick bed of clean straw rustling under his hooves. He immediately dropped his head to his haynet, but his ears remained pricked, one swivelling back towards her, still attuned to her distress. She unbuckled the girth with practiced, albeit trembling, fingers and slid the heavy Western saddle from his back, grunting as the movement sent a fresh spike of pain through her shoulder. She heaved it onto its rack, the familiar action a small anchor in the swirling chaos of her emotions.

She worked on autopilot, her body moving through the familiar post-ride ritual that normally brought her so much peace. She removed his bridle, replacing it with a soft headcollar, and began to groom him, the rhythmic scrape and flick of the curry comb against his coat a steadying metronome. She started with his neck, working her way back along his powerful body, her touch firm and reassuring. This was her apology to him. With every stroke, she tried to erase the memory of her panic, to replace the frantic energy she had flooded him with, with this calm, repetitive care. He leaned into her touch, his body relaxing under her hands, his earlier tension melting away. He was a forgiving creature, asking for nothing but clarity and kindness, two things she had spectacularly failed to provide just minutes ago. As she worked, she could still hear Dirk’s laughter in her head, a phantom echo that made her jaw clench. He hadn’t just seen her fall; he had seen her unravel. He had been given a key to a locked room inside her, a room she kept hidden from everyone, even herself most days.

When she moved to groom his other side—the side that had been clean—she had to face herself. Her reflection was a distorted caricature in the small, dusty window of the tack room. A wild-eyed woman with dirt smeared down one side of her face, her blonde braid unraveling, and a constellation of ochre dust covering her dark blue shirt and jeans. She looked like she’d been in a brawl and lost badly. Reaching up, she touched her forehead, her fingers tracing the almost invisible line of a tiny, crescent-shaped scar just at her hairline. She was five years old, visiting a cousin’s farm in the rural expanse of Wallonia. She’d been enchanted by the chickens, chasing a hen into the coop, all childish giggles and clumsy feet. She hadn’t seen the rooster in the corner, a huge, aggressive Ardenner, until it was too late. He had flown at her, a terrifying explosion of feathers and fury, trapping her against the rough wooden wall. She remembered the suffocating smell, the frantic beating of his wings against her face, the stabbing pain as his beak struck her forehead. Her cousin had pulled the bird off, but the terror had imprinted itself on her soul. Alectryonophobia. A ridiculous, polysyllabic name for a primal fear of being small, trapped, and attacked by something vicious and unpredictable. A fear Dirk’s ‘Generaal’ had resurrected with terrifying efficiency.

She finished with Balthazar, covering him with a light sheet against the evening chill and filling his water bucket with a slosh of fresh, cool water. He dipped his muzzle in immediately, drinking deeply. The routine was done. There was nothing left to do but pack her gear and go home to her sterile Antwerp apartment, where the only birds were pigeons on the windowsill, safely behind double-glazed glass. She could quit. She could sell her gear, find a new home for Balthazar—the thought was a physical blow, making her gasp—and retreat back to the city, conceding defeat. She could let Dirk have his victory. The thought was so repulsive, it tasted worse than the arena dust. It tasted like surrender. It tasted like her father, who had filled her head with stories of prairie justice and cowboy grit, only to shrink from every real-life challenge, retreating into his books until he faded away completely. She would not be him. She would not retreat.

Leaning her aching body against the stall door, she stared out into the darkening yard. The arena was empty now, a silent stage. The ghost of her humiliation still lingered there, but the fire of it was banking, hardening into something cold and solid. Resolve. Dirk thought he had found her breaking point. He thought he could use it to drive her away, to prove she was nothing more than a wealthy hobbyist playing dress-up. He had made a crucial mistake, though. He hadn't just exposed her greatest fear; he had handed her a new objective. The reining competition in three weeks wasn’t just about the tightest spins or the longest slides anymore. It was no longer about proving she belonged in his world. It was about proving she could master her own. She wasn’t just going to outride Dirk Martens. She was going to do it in a world that contained his rooster, and she would not flinch. The how was a terrifying, gaping void in her mind, but the what was suddenly crystal clear. She pushed herself off the door, the pain in her hip a dull, constant reminder of her fall. It was the price of a lesson, she decided. A lesson in what she was truly fighting for. Not a blue ribbon. She was fighting for the right to stand her ground.

The next morning, pain was her alarm clock. It wasn't the familiar, satisfying ache of well-worked muscles, but a sharp, punitive throb in her right shoulder and a deep, blooming soreness across her hip. Before she even opened her eyes to the soft grey light filtering into her Antwerp apartment, she knew there would be a mark. A souvenir from her downfall. Throwing back the minimalist white duvet, she padded into the bathroom, the cool tiles a stark contrast to the memory of warm dirt. She angled her body towards the mirror, twisting to see her hip. A spectacular bruise was taking shape, a chaotic galaxy of purple, blue, and an ugly shade of yellow, sprawling across her skin like a map of her disgrace. It was a tangible piece of evidence of her failure, a physical manifestation of Dirk’s mocking laughter.

Her apartment was the antithesis of the arena. It was a clean, quiet space on the fourth floor of a restored townhouse, with high ceilings, immaculate white walls, and carefully chosen Scandinavian furniture. The only dust was the kind that was whisked away weekly by a cleaning service. Here, the air tasted of freshly ground coffee and the faint, clean scent of laundry detergent. The soundtrack was the civilized hiss of her espresso machine and the distant, reassuring rumble of a city tram. It was a life she had carefully curated, a fortress of order and control. A life her father would have called sterile. He had craved the dust, the chaos, the mythical grit of a life he’d only ever read about. She had built a world without it, only to find herself willingly driving an hour out of the city three times a week to roll around in it. The irony was not lost on her. She sipped her espresso, standing by the large window overlooking the street, and felt the chasm between her two lives yawn wider than ever before.

She couldn’t outride the memory. Every time she closed her eyes, she saw it: the arrogant strut of the cockerel, the blur of the ground rushing up to meet her, the sound of Dirk’s laughter. Humiliation was a poor motivator, but anger was a powerful fuel. The vow she had made in the dim light of the stable had survived the night, hardening from a heated promise into a cold, calculated objective. But resolve was one thing; a plan was another. She sat down at her sleek glass desk, the city waking up below her, and opened her laptop. The search bar was a stark white confessional.

*Fear of chickens phobia.*

Alectryonophobia. The word itself was ridiculous, a mouthful of Greek that felt too academic, too tame for the heart-pounding, world-tilting terror she experienced. She scrolled past amateur forums filled with stories that were unhelpfully similar to her own and looked for something more concrete. Treatment. Cures. She found articles on Cognitive Behavioural Therapy and, more compellingly, exposure therapy. The concept was brutal in its simplicity: deliberately and repeatedly expose yourself to the source of your fear, in controlled increments, until the panic response diminishes. Until the brain learns that the feathered demon is, in fact, just a bird. It was the psychological equivalent of pressing on a bruise to see if it still hurt.

Her hands were steady as she typed a new search: *rooster*. The image search page loaded, a horrifying mosaic of blood-red combs, iridescent feathers, and sharp, accusatory eyes. Her heart rate kicked up immediately. Her breath hitched. She could feel a cold sweat prickle at her hairline. She forced herself to look. To not click away. She stared at a picture of a particularly magnificent specimen, its chest puffed out in a silent crow, and focused on the details. The intricate pattern of its feathers. The way the light caught its obsidian eye. She mentally dismantled it, breaking it down from a monster into a collection of biological parts. *It’s just an animal. It weighs less than Balthazar’s saddle blanket. It has a brain the size of a walnut.* She repeated the words like a mantra, her knuckles white on the edge of her desk. After five long, excruciating minutes, she closed the tab, her body trembling slightly but intact. Step one, complete.

The next steps would require leaving her fortress. Images on a screen were one thing; sound and smell and movement were another. She needed a new kind of arena, one with a different kind of challenge. Her fingers flew across the keyboard again. *Kinderboerderij Antwerpen*. A children’s petting farm. The idea was almost comical. A lone woman, thirty-two years old, striding into a haven of squealing children and docile farm animals on a mission of psychological warfare. The farm’s website showed pictures of fluffy bunnies, placid-looking goats, and, crucially, a fenced-in chicken run. The birds looked small and non-threatening, mostly brown hens scratching peacefully in the dirt. It was perfect. A low-stakes training ground. It was miles away from the belligerent alpha-male arrogance of Generaal. It was basic training before facing the general himself. She checked the opening times, a knot of dread and determination tightening in her stomach. It was a battle plan. And the first skirmish was scheduled for noon.

The Kinderboerderij was an assault of cheerful noise and primary colours. The squeals of delighted children mixed with the bleating of pygmy goats and the indignant honking of a territorial goose. A brightly painted sign with a cartoon cow welcomed visitors into a world of manicured lawns and child-safe fencing. Lena felt deeply, profoundly out of place. She wore simple jeans and a grey t-shirt, no hat, no boots, an anonymous civilian on a clandestine mission. She paid the small entrance fee to a teenager who barely glanced up from her phone, the transaction feeling illicit, as though she were buying entry into her own private coliseum of fear. Around her, young parents pushed strollers and pointed out fluffy bunnies to wide-eyed toddlers. Lena was an anomaly, a solitary adult with a grim set to her jaw, navigating a landscape of innocent joy with the focus of a bomb disposal expert.

She found the chicken run at the far end of the farm, tucked away behind the pigsty. It was a large, wire-mesh enclosure, shaded by a sprawling chestnut tree. A dozen or so hens, a mix of placid brown and white breeds, scratched in the dirt or pecked at a feeder. There was no proud strutting, no challenging crows, and most importantly, no rooster. The immediate wave of relief that washed over her was so profound it made her feel sick with self-loathing. This was the enemy she had girded herself to face? A flock of docile, clucking birds that were more interested in dropped breadcrumbs than the terrified woman staring at them from behind the safety of a fence. The gap between the rational and the primal had never felt so vast.

Taking a deep, unsteadying breath, she began to walk towards the enclosure. The air, thick with the smell of damp earth and pig, was now tainted with that other scent—the dry, dusty odour of feathers and bird droppings that was inextricably linked to suffocating panic. The gentle, conversational clucking of the hens was a harmless background noise to everyone else, but to her, it was the low-level hum of an impending threat. She stopped about fifteen feet away, her hands finding each other and linking in a white-knuckled grip. Her heart was a frantic drum against her ribs. *Breathe,* she commanded herself, the order getting lost somewhere between her brain and her lungs. *They can't get to you. They are in a cage. You are not.* She was trying to reason with a terror that had no capacity for logic.

She stood there for a full minute, a statue of anxiety, just watching. A fat brown hen had a brief, comical squabble with another over a particularly interesting patch of dirt. A white one with fluffy legs pecked at its own reflection in a small puddle. They were absurd. They were harmless. And yet, the faulty wiring in her brain was screaming at her to run, to put distance between herself and the memory they represented. She forced the image of Dirk’s mocking face into her mind, superimposing it over the scene. She felt the ghost of the impact as she hit the arena floor, the grit of the dirt in her teeth. Humiliation was a bitter pill, but it was a powerful antidote to flight. The desire not to let him win, not to be broken by his casual cruelty, was the only thing keeping her feet rooted to the spot.

“Look, Mommy! Chickens!” A little boy, no more than four, with a smear of chocolate on his cheek, ran past her and pressed his face against the wire fence. His mother followed at a more leisurely pace, a weary but fond smile on her face. Her eyes met Lena’s for a moment, and her smile faltered. She took in Lena’s rigid posture, the intensity of her stare, the unnatural stillness of her body. The mother’s expression shifted from casual friendliness to a subtle, protective watchfulness. She put a hand on her son’s shoulder, a gesture that was both reassuring for him and territorial against the strange woman who was staring at the poultry with the unnerving focus of a predator. Lena felt the silent judgment like a physical touch, and a fresh wave of shame washed over her. She didn't just feel afraid; she felt freakish, her private horror now a public spectacle for one.

Ignoring the mother and child, she forced herself to take three more steps, bringing her right to the fence line. Her breath hitched, but she didn't retreat. She was close enough now to see the details she had tried to study on her laptop screen. The intricate, overlapping pattern of feathers, the bright, unblinking eyes, the scaly, alien-like legs. She focused on one hen, a plain brown one, and did as the articles suggested. She narrated its actions in her head. *The chicken is pecking the ground. The chicken is walking. The chicken is ruffling its feathers.* She broke it down into a series of mundane, unthreatening actions, stripping it of its monstrous power. She stayed there, her hands gripping the top rail of the wooden fence, until the mother and son had moved on to the goats, and then for five minutes after that. The terror didn't vanish, but its sharp edges began to dull. The frantic drumming in her chest eased to a heavy, insistent pounding. She had not panicked. She had not run.

When she finally let go of the fence and turned away, her muscles were so tense they ached, and her legs felt unsteady. She walked back towards the entrance, feeling hollowed out and utterly drained. The cheerful sounds of the farm seemed distant and distorted. But as she pushed through the exit gate and back into the anonymous city streets, she felt a flicker of something new. It wasn't pride, and it certainly wasn't courage. It was a grim, hard-won sense of accomplishment. She had gone into the belly of the beast—or at least, its nursery—and she had walked out on her own two feet. Driving back to her apartment, the lurid bruise on her hip pulsed with a dull ache, a constant reminder of the stakes. Today it was a petting farm. Tomorrow, she would go back to the stables. She wouldn't ride. She would just stand her ground.

## Chapter 2

The drive back to the Kempen region the next evening felt like a pilgrimage to a site of personal disaster. Every kilometre brought the memory of her fall into sharper focus. The bruise on her hip was a constant, nagging companion, a dull ache that flared every time she shifted in the driver’s seat. She had bypassed her usual riding clothes, the denim and worn leather that felt like a costume she hadn’t yet earned the right to wear. Instead, she was in old work trousers and a plain black sweater, dressed for a chore, not for a passion. She was not a cowgirl today. She was an exterminator, and the pest she had come to deal with lived inside her own head. She parked her car not in its usual spot near the arena, but further away, by a cluster of old oak trees, giving herself a longer walk, a few more seconds to steel her nerves. The air was already cooler, carrying the scent of damp earth and the distant, familiar perfume of horses. It was a smell that usually calmed her, but tonight it was laced with the metallic tang of anxiety.

Her first stop was Balthazar’s stall. The moment she slid open the heavy wooden door, he lifted his head from his hay, his ears pricked forward in greeting. He let out a low, welcoming nicker, and the knot of tension in Lena's chest loosened, just a fraction. She went to him, her hands finding the familiar, solid warmth of his neck. She pressed her forehead against him, breathing in his scent, letting his quiet strength seep into her. He stood perfectly still, a silent, steady anchor in her turbulent world. For a long while, she just stood there, grooming him with slow, methodical strokes, not because he was dirty, but because the repetitive motion was a meditation. It was a way of reminding herself what was real, what was good. This solid creature, this unspoken trust. This was worth fighting for. The thought of Dirk Martens making her give this up was an obscenity.

Finally, she couldn't put it off any longer. Leaving Balthazar with a final pat and a whispered promise, she took a deep breath and stepped out of the relative safety of the stables into the main yard. The low sun cast long, menacing shadows that stretched like grasping fingers across the dusty ground. The arena was empty, a silent testament to her failure. And there, leaning against the fence in almost the exact same spot as the day before, was Dirk. It was as if he’d been waiting for her. He had a length of rope in his hands, mending a lead, his movements slow and deliberate. He didn’t look up immediately, letting her walk a few paces into the open before he acknowledged her.

“Well, look what the cat dragged in,” he drawled, his voice carrying easily in the still air. He finally raised his eyes to meet hers, a smirk already in place. “Came back for another lesson in dirt-tasting? I’m surprised. Figured you’d have packed up your fancy saddle and run back to the city by now.”

Lena stopped, her boots planted in the dirt about twenty feet from him. She crossed her arms over her chest, a defensive posture that she hoped read as casual defiance. “You’d like that, wouldn’t you, Dirk? One less ‘city girl’ to worry about in the competition.” She kept her voice even, a flat, calm tone that cost her more effort than a full reining pattern.

He chuckled, a low, condescending sound. “Competition? Honey, you’re not my competition. Not if you’re going to get spooked by the livestock.” He gestured with his head towards the stables. “Speaking of which, the Generaal is holding court by the water trough. You might want to make a wide circle. Wouldn’t want you to faint from terror.”

Her eyes darted instinctively towards the trough, a stone basin near the corner of the stable she’d just left. And there he was. The cockerel. He was standing on the edge of the basin, his iridescent tail-feathers catching the golden light of the setting sun, making him look like a creature forged from oil and fire. He dipped his beak, took a drink, and then raised his head, a single drop of water clinging to the tip of his beak before it fell. He was just a bird, drinking water. Yet the sight of him sent a jolt of pure adrenaline through her system. Her heart began to pound, a familiar, sickening rhythm. Her palms grew damp. The urge to turn, to walk quickly and calmly back to her car and drive away, was a physical force, a magnetic pull.

She didn't move. She forced her feet to stay planted, her boots sinking slightly into the soft dirt. She mimicked the exercise from the petting farm, narrating the scene in her head with a frantic, internal monologue. *It is a chicken. It is drinking water. It is not looking at you. It is ten metres away. It cannot fly that far. You are safe.* It felt like arguing with a hurricane. Dirk was watching her, his eyes narrowed, that smug smirk fixed on his face. He was waiting for her to break. He was enjoying this. The anger that thought provoked was a welcome surge of heat, a counter-current to the icy wave of fear. She uncrossed her arms and let them hang by her sides, forcing a relaxation she did not feel. She was a statue, brittle and cold, but she was not running.

The Generaal, finished with its drink, hopped down from the trough. It shook its feathers in a quick, rattling shimmy and began to strut, not towards her, but parallel to the stable wall, its head bobbing with that infuriating, clockwork arrogance. Every jerky step was a fresh spike of anxiety in Lena’s brain. She could feel a fine tremor starting in her hands. She curled them into loose fists, digging her fingernails into her palms, the small, sharp pain a welcome distraction, an anchor. She didn’t take her eyes off the bird, tracking its every move. She was a soldier, and this was her minefield. Dirk’s voice cut through her hyper-focus, laced with a fresh note of annoyance.

“You’re a strange one, Verhoeven,” he said, pushing himself off the fence. The casual amusement was gone from his tone, replaced by something sharper. “Most people, when they’re scared of something, they run away. You just stand there and stare at it like you’re trying to set it on fire with your mind.”

“Maybe I’m just admiring your prize-winner, Dirk,” she replied, her voice tight. “Wondering what makes him so special.”

“He’s got spirit. Grit,” Dirk said, the words a clear echo of their previous conversation. “Something you wouldn’t understand.” He coiled the rope he’d been mending and hung it on a nail on the fencepost. The finality of the action felt like a dismissal. He had expected a show, a repeat of yesterday’s drama, and she had denied it to him. She hadn't won, not by any stretch of the imagination, but she hadn’t lost in the way he’d anticipated. She had simply endured.

Without another word, he turned his back on her and strode towards the farmhouse on the hill, his boots kicking up little puffs of dust. He didn’t look back. Lena stood there for another long moment, her gaze still locked on the cockerel, who was now pecking at something unseen in the dirt. The bird was oblivious. It had no idea of the war that had just been waged in its name. Slowly, deliberately, Lena let out the breath she felt like she had been holding for an eternity. Her body was awash with the jittery, draining aftermath of adrenaline. She was exhausted, hollowed out, but she was still standing. As the last sliver of the sun disappeared behind the trees, casting the yard in a deep blue twilight, she finally turned and walked back towards her car. She hadn't run. And for tonight, that was a victory.

## Chapter 3

The small victory felt achingly temporary. Back in the sterile sanctuary of her apartment, Lena showered away the grime of the yard, the hot water stinging her bruised hip. The adrenaline had long since evaporated, leaving behind a bone-deep weariness and a frustrating, buzzing anxiety that settled under her skin. She had stood her ground, yes, but the fear had been a living thing inside her, a parasite feeding on her energy. She had starved it of the reaction it wanted, but it was still there, coiled and waiting. Sleep offered little respite, her dreams a chaotic montage of iridescent feathers, the jarring impact of the fall, and her father’s disappointed face superimposed over Dirk’s mocking smirk. She woke up feeling like she’d run a marathon, not simply stood in a yard for ten minutes. The path forward was clear in its objective, but terrifying in its execution. Enduring was not enough. She had to function. She had to ride.

For the next two days, she repeated the ritual. She drove to the stables in the late afternoon, her stomach a cold knot of dread. She would spend time with Balthazar, drawing strength from his calm presence, the stable her fortified command post. Then, she would walk out into the yard. Dirk was sometimes there, sometimes not, but his prize-winning cockerel was a constant. The Generaal patrolled his territory with unwavering pomposity, and each day Lena would force herself to stand there, watching him, her heart hammering, her hands trembling, until the initial spike of panic subsided into a low-grade, exhausting hum of terror. She learned his routines: the way he sunned himself on a particular fence post, his preferred patch of dirt for dust baths, the sharp, interrogating squawk he gave whenever a car pulled into the yard. She was studying the enemy, gathering intelligence, her fear becoming grimly analytical. She was not getting less scared, but she was getting better at functioning while being scared.

On the third day, she arrived in her riding gear. The familiar weight of her boots, the worn denim of her jeans, felt both like an act of defiance and a terrible folly. Tacking up Balthazar, her hands moved with a slight tremor she couldn’t control. She checked the girth three times, adjusted the bridle twice, her movements fussy and uncertain. Balthazar, ever the barometer of her soul, felt it all. He shifted his weight, his ears twitching, his soft eyes watching her with a questioning unease. “It’s okay, boy,” she whispered, her voice a dry rasp. “We’re just going for a walk.” It was a lie, and they both knew it. She led him out of the stable, her gaze sweeping the yard. No Dirk. No Generaal. A small, treacherous pocket of relief opened in her chest. Maybe this would be easy.

The moment Balthazar’s hooves touched the soft, deep dust of the arena, he tensed. He remembered. The memory of her panic, of the sudden, sharp command and the unbalanced rear, was stored in his muscles just as it was in hers. She swung a leg over the saddle, her sore hip protesting, and settled into the familiar leather seat. It didn't feel like home. It felt like the cockpit of a malfunctioning aircraft. Her hands on the reins were rigid, her legs stiff against his sides. She asked him to walk the rail, a simple, basic request, but her tense body was sending a dozen contradictory signals. *Go. Stop. Danger. It’s fine.* He moved, but his walk was choppy and hesitant, his head held unnaturally high, his ears swivelling frantically, searching for the source of her fear.

It was a miserable ride. Every rustle of wind in the corrugated iron roof made her jump. Every shadow seemed to hold the shape of a feathered monster. She tried to guide Balthazar through the gentle curves of a serpentine, but her focus was shot. Her cues were clumsy, her body a block of solid tension. Balthazar, confused and anxious, kept breaking gait, his trust in her eroding with every rigid signal she sent him. The fluid partnership they had built through years of obsessive practice was gone, replaced by a clumsy, fearful dance between a terrified rider and her worried horse. Humiliation was a fresh, hot flush on her cheeks. She couldn't even ride a simple walk circle. Dirk didn't need a rooster to prove she was a failure; she was doing a fine job of it all by herself.

She was so wrapped up in her own miserable performance that she didn't see the man until he was right by the arena fence. He was older, maybe in his late sixties, with a face as weathered as old leather and kind, crinkling eyes. It was Jos, the old stable hand who had worked on the Martens’ farm since before Dirk was born. He moved with the slow, deliberate economy of a man who had spent a lifetime around horses, and he was watching her, his expression unreadable. He held a pitchfork, but he rested it against the fence, giving her his full attention.

“He feels heavy in your hands today, Lena,” Jos said, his voice a low, gravelly rumble. It wasn't a criticism, just an observation.

Lena pulled Balthazar to a clumsy halt, her frustration making her want to snap. “He’s tense,” she said, the words clipped.

Jos nodded slowly, his gaze drifting from her white-knuckled hands on the reins to Balthazar’s anxious, twitching ears. “The horse is a mirror,” he said simply. He didn’t mention the fall. The cockerel, emboldened, hopped closer, perilously near the neat line of shiny new horseshoes Frank had laid out on a piece of leather. He was staring at her, his mouth slightly agape, his eyes wide with a look of utter, unadulterated shock. He hadn't just seen her stand her ground. He had seen her, without fear or hesitation, treat his prize-winning, terror-inducing feathered demon like a common pest. It was as if she had casually swatted a fly that he had always believed was a dragon. The foundation of his perception of her had just been irrevocably shattered.

Then his eyes drifted back to her, and for the first time, she saw not anger, not derision, not even grudging respect, but pure, unvarnished bewilderment. She had discovered that true grit wasn't about the absence of fear, but about the presence of courage, a quiet, stubborn force that was not for show, but for the sake of what you loved. It wasn't about being a lone cowgirl, but about being a reliable partner. It was a lesson learned in dust and humiliation, taught by a wise old man, a belligerent rooster, and the best damn horse a city girl could ever ask for. ## Chapter 11

The journey back through the darkening woods was a slow, solemn procession. The world had narrowed to the small circle of their shared crisis. Lena walked on the left, her hand resting on Balthazar's shoulder, a steadying point of contact. He was, for the first time, experiencing her world not as a critic from the fenceline, but from the inside, from the saddle. He felt the trust her horse placed in her, the quiet communication that passed between them, and he understood, in a way no competition ever could have taught him, the source of her strength. It wasn't about money or fancy gear; it was about this. This quiet, unshakeable partnership.
